stem: The case manager is coordinating discharge for a client who sustained multiple injuries in a motor vehicle accident. Based on the client's documented deficits in the EHR, match the client's need to the most appropriate interdisciplinary team member.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00: Client (28-year-old male) status-post ORIF of right femur and mild TBI. 
08:30: Client reports he is worried about how he will pay for his medications after discharge as he lost his job due to the accident. 
09:00: Occupational therapist reports client has difficulty with motor planning during upper body dressing. 
09:30: During lunch, client was noted to have a persistent 'wet' sounding voice and coughs after swallowing thin liquids. 
10:00: Client expresses profound grief over the death of his passenger in the accident and asks, 'Why did I survive when they didn't?'

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
ConditionStatusNote
PainControlled4/10 with ibuprofen
MobilityImpairedRequires 2-person assist for pivot transfer
SwallowingAt RiskNPO until evaluation

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Musculoskeletal: Right leg in a long leg immobilizer. Left arm strength 5/5. 
Neuro: Alert, follows simple commands but exhibits short-term memory deficits. 
Psychosocial: Tearful, avoids eye contact, expresses guilt.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
1. Mobility training with assistive devices. 
2. Activities of Daily Living (ADL) retraining. 
3. Evaluation of safety during oral intake. 
4. Financial and community resource assessment. 
5. Psychosocial/Spiritual support.

rows.text: Difficulty with motor planning during upper body dressing
Persistent 'wet' voice and coughing after swallowing thin liquids
Lack of financial resources and insurance for medications
Difficulty with transfers and gait training with a walker
Profound grief and questioning the meaning of survival

rationale.correct: Occupational therapy (OT) focuses on ADLs and upper body function (r1). Speech-Language Pathologists (SLP) evaluate swallowing safety (r2). Social Workers (SW) manage financial and resource needs (r3). Physical Therapy (PT) focuses on gross motor skills like gait and transfers (r4). Spiritual Care or Chaplains address existential/spiritual distress and grief (r5).
clinicalPearls: Occupational Therapy (OT) focuses on Activities of Daily Living (ADLs) such as dressing, bathing, and eating.
Physical Therapy (PT) focuses on large muscle movements such as walking, climbing, and transferring.
If a patient coughs while drinking, keep them NPO and consult with a Speech-Language Pathologist (SLP) immediately.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: Occupational Therapy (OT) addresses fine motor skills and daily tasks, while Physical Therapy (PT) addresses gross motor skills and mobility.

mnemonic.title: Referral Quick-Check
mnemonic.expansion: PT (Power/Pavement): Physical Therapy. OT (Object/Occupation): Occupational Therapy. SLP (Swallow/Speak): Speech-Language Pathologist. SW (Scents/Social support): Social Worker.
